plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A beloved ornamental tree known for its large, fragrant, cup-shaped flowers that appear before the leaves in early spring. The blooms are usually pink, white, or purple, creating spectacular displays in temperate regions.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer Magnolias bloom on old wood, meaning the flowers appear on last year's growth, often before the leaves.

plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A spring-flowering bulb native to Europe, producing bright yellow, trumpet-shaped flowers on slender stems. It thrives in woodlands, meadows, and along riverbanks.
plants.funFact: Wild daffodils are among the first wildflowers to bloom, often forming carpets in ancient woodland areas.

plants.name: Prunus serrulata
plants.description: Famous for its spectacular, ephemeral pink or white flowers that bloom in early to mid-spring. These ornamental cherries are culturally significant in Japan and other parts of the world.
plants.location: Japan, Korea, China, and temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Cherry blossoms bloom for a very short period, typically lasting only a week or two, symbolizing the fleeting nature of life.

plants.name: Acacia dealbata
plants.description: An evergreen shrub or small tree native to southeastern Australia, noted for its fluffy, bright yellow flower clusters that bloom in late winter and early spring.
plants.location: Australia (native); cultivated in Mediterranean climates worldwide
plants.funFact: The bright yellow flowers of Acacia dealbata were traditionally used as a symbol of International Women's Day in some countries.
